# Colors
insert_n_curves(self, n)
insert_n_curves_to_point_list(self, n, points)
interpolate_color(self, mobject1, mobject2, alpha)
is_closed(self)
make_jagged(self)
make_smooth(self)
match_background_image_file(self, vmobject)
match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)
point_from_proportion(self, alpha)
pointwise_become_partial(self, vmobject, a, b)
scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_opacity(self, opacity, family=True)
set_points(self, points)
# Points
set_points_as_corners(self, points)
set_points_smoothly(self, points)
set_shade_in_3d(self, value=True, z_index_as_group=False)
set_sheen(self, factor, direction=None, family=True)
set_sheen_direction(self, direction, family=True)
set_stroke(self, color=None, width=None, opacity=None, background=False, family=True)
set_style(self, fill_color=None, fill_opacity=None, stroke_color=None, stroke_width=None, stroke_opacity=None, background_stroke_color=None, background_stroke_width=None, background_stroke_opacity=None, sheen_factor=None, sheen_direction=None, background_image_file=None, family=True)
start_new_path(self, point)
update_rgbas_array(self, array_name, color=None, opacity=None)

# Background rectangle
add_background_rectangle_to_family_members_with_points(self, **kwargs)
add_background_rectangle_to_submobjects(self, **kwargs)
add_n_more_submobjects(self, n)
add_to_back(self, *mobjects)
add_updater(self, update_function, index=None, call_updater=True)
align_data(self, mobject)
# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2
apply_complex_function(self, function, **kwargs)
apply_function_to_position(self, function)
apply_function_to_submobject_positions(self, function)
apply_matrix(self, matrix, **kwargs)
apply_over_attr_arrays(self, func)
apply_points_function_about_point(self, func, about_point=None, about_edge=None)
apply_to_family(self, func)
arrange(self, direction=array([1., 0., 0.]), center=True, **kwargs)
arrange_in_grid(self, n_rows=None, n_cols=None, **kwargs)
arrange_submobjects(self, *args, **kwargs)
# Just here to keep from breaking old scenes.
become(self, mobject, copy_submobjects=True)
Edit points, colors and submobjects to be idential
to another mobject
become_partial(self, mobject, a, b)
Set points in such a way as to become only
part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.
center(self)
clear_updaters(self, recursive=True)
copy(self)
deepcopy(self)
digest_mobject_attrs(self)
Ensures all attributes which are mobjects are included
in the submobjects list.

get_bottom(self)

get_center(self)
get_center_of_mass(self)
get_coord(self, dim, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
Meant to generalize get_x, get_y, get_z
get_corner(self, direction)
get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

nonempty_submobjects(self)
null_point_align(self, mobject)
If a mobject with points is being aligned to
one without, treat both as groups, and push
the one with points into its own submobjects
list.
pose_at_angle(self, **kwargs)

repeat_submobject(self, submob)

rescale_to_fit(self, length, dim, stretch=False, **kwargs)

resume_updating(self, recursive=True)
reverse_points(self)

rotate_about_origin(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]), axes=[])
rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))
save_image(self, name=None)
save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
set_color_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')

set_height(self, height, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_submobject_colors_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_submobject_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')
set_width(self, width, stretch=False, **kwargs)

set_y(self, y, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_z(self, z, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))

If two points are passed in, the first is intepretted
as a handle, the second as an anchor

apply_function(self, function)

color_using_background_image(self, background_image_file)
consider_points_equals(self, p0, p1)
fade(self, darkness=0.5, family=True)
generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))
get_arc_length(self, n_sample_points=None)
get_background_image_file(self)
get_color(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples_from_points(self, points)
# Information about line
get_end_anchors(self)
get_fill_color(self)
If there are multiple colors (for gradient)
this returns the first one
get_fill_colors(self)
get_fill_opacities(self)
get_fill_opacity(self)
If there are multiple opacities, this returns the
first
get_fill_rgbas(self)
get_gradient_start_and_end_points(self)

get_last_point(self)

anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d

again.

rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))
save_image(self, name=None)
save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
set_color_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')
set_coord(self, value, dim, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_depth(self, depth, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_height(self, height, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_submobject_colors_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_submobject_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')
set_width(self, width, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_x(self, x, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_y(self, y, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_z(self, z, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
shift(self, *vectors)
shift_onto_screen(self, **kwargs)
show(self, camera=None)
shuffle(self, recursive=False)

space_out_submobjects(self, factor=1.5, **kwargs)
split(self)
stretch(self, factor, dim, **kwargs)
stretch_about_point(self, factor, dim, point)
stretch_in_place(self, factor, dim)
stretch_to_fit_depth(self, depth, **kwargs)

dictionary for instance variables (if defined)

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

 
class Sector(AnnularSector)
    Sector(start_angle=0, angle=1.5707963267948966, **kwargs)
 
Meant for shared functionality between Arc and Line.
Functionality can be classified broadly into these groups:
 
    * Adding, Creating, Modifying tips
        - add_tip calls create_tip, before pushing the new tip
            into the TipableVMobject's list of submobjects
        - stylistic and positional configuration
 
    * Checking for tips
        - Boolean checks for whether the TipableVMobject has a tip
            and a starting tip
 
    * Getters
        - Straightforward accessors, returning information pertaining
            to the TipableVMobject instance's tip(s), its length etc
 
 
Method resolution order:
Sector
AnnularSector
Arc
TipableVMobject
manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject
manimlib.mobject.mobject.Mobject
manimlib.container.container.Container
builtins.object
Data and other attributes defined here:
CONFIG = {'inner_radius': 0, 'outer_radius': 1}

anchors, and finds their intersection points

a 'starting tip' or not.

generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))

match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)

pointwise_become_partial(self, vmobject, a, b)
scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_opacity(self, opacity, family=True)

# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2

part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.

get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

class SmallDot(Dot)
    SmallDot(point=array([0., 0., 0.]), **kwargs)
 
Meant for shared functionality between Arc and Line.
Functionality can be classified broadly into these groups:
 
    * Adding, Creating, Modifying tips
        - add_tip calls create_tip, before pushing the new tip
            into the TipableVMobject's list of submobjects
        - stylistic and positional configuration
 
    * Checking for tips
        - Boolean checks for whether the TipableVMobject has a tip
            and a starting tip
 
    * Getters
        - Straightforward accessors, returning information pertaining
            to the TipableVMobject instance's tip(s), its length etc

as a handle, the second as an anchor
add_subpath(self, points)
align_points(self, vmobject)
# Alignment
align_rgbas(self, vmobject)
append_points(self, new_points)
append_vectorized_mobject(self, vectorized_mobject)
apply_function(self, function)
change_anchor_mode(self, mode)
clear_points(self)
color_using_background_image(self, background_image_file)
consider_points_equals(self, p0, p1)
fade(self, darkness=0.5, family=True)
generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))
get_arc_length(self, n_sample_points=None)
get_background_image_file(self)
get_color(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples_from_points(self, points)
# Information about line
get_end_anchors(self)
get_fill_color(self)
If there are multiple colors (for gradient)
this returns the first one
get_fill_colors(self)
get_fill_opacities(self)
get_fill_opacity(self)
If there are multiple opacities, this returns the
first
get_fill_rgbas(self)
get_gradient_start_and_end_points(self)
get_group_class(self)
get_last_point(self)
get_nth_curve_function(self, n)
get_nth_curve_points(self, n)
get_num_curves(self)
get_point_mobject(self, center=None)
The simplest mobject to be transformed to or from self.
Should by a point of the appropriate type
get_points(self)
get_points_defining_boundary(self)
get_sheen_direction(self)
get_sheen_factor(self)
get_start_anchors(self)
get_stroke_color(self, background=False)
get_stroke_colors(self, background=False)
get_stroke_opacities(self, background=False)
get_stroke_opacity(self, background=False)
get_stroke_rgbas(self, background=False)
get_stroke_width(self, background=False)
get_style(self)
get_subcurve(self, a, b)
get_subpaths(self)
get_subpaths_from_points(self, points)
has_new_path_started(self)
init_colors(self)
# Colors
insert_n_curves(self, n)
insert_n_curves_to_point_list(self, n, points)
interpolate_color(self, mobject1, mobject2, alpha)
is_closed(self)
make_jagged(self)
make_smooth(self)
match_background_image_file(self, vmobject)
match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)
point_from_proportion(self, alpha)
pointwise_become_partial(self, vmobject, a, b)
scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_opacity(self, opacity, family=True)
set_points(self, points)
# Points
set_points_as_corners(self, points)
set_points_smoothly(self, points)
set_shade_in_3d(self, value=True, z_index_as_group=False)
set_sheen(self, factor, direction=None, family=True)
set_sheen_direction(self, direction, family=True)
set_stroke(self, color=None, width=None, opacity=None, background=False, family=True)
set_style(self, fill_color=None, fill_opacity=None, stroke_color=None, stroke_width=None, stroke_opacity=None, background_stroke_color=None, background_stroke_width=None, background_stroke_opacity=None, sheen_factor=None, sheen_direction=None, background_image_file=None, family=True)
start_new_path(self, point)
update_rgbas_array(self, array_name, color=None, opacity=None)

add_updater(self, update_function, index=None, call_updater=True)
align_data(self, mobject)
# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2
apply_complex_function(self, function, **kwargs)
apply_function_to_position(self, function)
apply_function_to_submobject_positions(self, function)
apply_matrix(self, matrix, **kwargs)

apply_to_family(self, func)

arrange_in_grid(self, n_rows=None, n_cols=None, **kwargs)
arrange_submobjects(self, *args, **kwargs)
# Just here to keep from breaking old scenes.
become(self, mobject, copy_submobjects=True)
Edit points, colors and submobjects to be idential
to another mobject
become_partial(self, mobject, a, b)
Set points in such a way as to become only
part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.
center(self)
clear_updaters(self, recursive=True)

in the submobjects list.

Meant to generalize get_x, get_y, get_z
get_corner(self, direction)
get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

null_point_align(self, mobject)
If a mobject with points is being aligned to
one without, treat both as groups, and push
the one with points into its own submobjects
list.
pose_at_angle(self, **kwargs)

reverse_points(self)

rotate_about_origin(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]), axes=[])
rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))
save_image(self, name=None)
save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
set_color_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')

one color was passed in, a second slightly light color

scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.

function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.

If a mobject with points is being aligned to
one without, treat both as groups, and push
the one with points into its own submobjects
list.

rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))

save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)

set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')

set_width(self, width, stretch=False, **kwargs)

set_y(self, y, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_z(self, z, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))

__weakref__
list of weak references to the object (if defined)

 
class TangentLine(Line)
    TangentLine(vmob, alpha, **kwargs)
 
Meant for shared functionality between Arc and Line.
Functionality can be classified broadly into these groups:
 
    * Adding, Creating, Modifying tips
        - add_tip calls create_tip, before pushing the new tip
            into the TipableVMobject's list of submobjects
        - stylistic and positional configuration
 
    * Checking for tips
        - Boolean checks for whether the TipableVMobject has a tip
            and a starting tip
 
    * Getters
        - Straightforward accessors, returning information pertaining
            to the TipableVMobject instance's tip(s), its length etc
 
 
Method resolution order:
TangentLine
Line
TipableVMobject
manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject
manimlib.mobject.mobject.Mobject
manimlib.container.container.Container
builtins.object
Methods defined here:
__init__(self, vmob, alpha, **kwargs)
Initialize self.  See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.
Data and other attributes defined here:
CONFIG = {'d_alpha': 1e-06, 'length': 1}

add_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Adds a tip to the TipableVMobject instance, recognising
that the endpoints might need to be switched if it's
a 'starting tip' or not.

create_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Stylises the tip, positions it spacially, and returns
the newly instantiated tip to the caller.

generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))

match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)

scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_points(self, points)

# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2

part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.

get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

class TipableVMobject(manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject)
    TipableVMobject(**kwargs)
 
Meant for shared functionality between Arc and Line.
Functionality can be classified broadly into these groups:
 
    * Adding, Creating, Modifying tips
        - add_tip calls create_tip, before pushing the new tip
            into the TipableVMobject's list of submobjects
        - stylistic and positional configuration
 
    * Checking for tips
        - Boolean checks for whether the TipableVMobject has a tip
            and a starting tip
 
    * Getters
        - Straightforward accessors, returning information pertaining
            to the TipableVMobject instance's tip(s), its length etc
 
 
Method resolution order:
TipableVMobject
manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject
manimlib.mobject.mobject.Mobject
manimlib.container.container.Container
builtins.object
Methods defined here:
add_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Adds a tip to the TipableVMobject instance, recognising
that the endpoints might need to be switched if it's
a 'starting tip' or not.
asign_tip_attr(self, tip, at_start)
create_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Stylises the tip, positions it spacially, and returns
the newly instantiated tip to the caller.
get_default_tip_length(self)
get_end(self)
get_first_handle(self)
get_last_handle(self)
get_length(self)
get_start(self)
get_tip(self)
Returns the TipableVMobject instance's (first) tip,
otherwise throws an exception.
get_tips(self)
Returns a VGroup (collection of VMobjects) containing
the TipableVMObject instance's tips.
get_unpositioned_tip(self, tip_length=None)
Returns a tip that has been stylistically configured,
but has not yet been given a position in space.
has_start_tip(self)
has_tip(self)
pop_tips(self)
position_tip(self, tip, at_start=False)
reset_endpoints_based_on_tip(self, tip, at_start)
Data and other attributes defined here:
CONFIG = {'normal_vector': array([0., 0., 1.]), 'tip_length': 0.35, 'tip_style': {'fill_opacity': 1, 'stroke_width': 0}}
Methods inherited from manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject:
add_cubic_bezier_curve(self, anchor1, handle1, handle2, anchor2)
add_cubic_bezier_curve_to(self, handle1, handle2, anchor)
Add cubic bezier curve to the path.
add_line_to(self, point)
add_points_as_corners(self, points)
add_smooth_curve_to(self, *points)
If two points are passed in, the first is intepretted
as a handle, the second as an anchor
add_subpath(self, points)
align_points(self, vmobject)
# Alignment
align_rgbas(self, vmobject)
append_points(self, new_points)
append_vectorized_mobject(self, vectorized_mobject)
apply_function(self, function)
change_anchor_mode(self, mode)
clear_points(self)
color_using_background_image(self, background_image_file)
consider_points_equals(self, p0, p1)
fade(self, darkness=0.5, family=True)
generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))
get_arc_length(self, n_sample_points=None)
get_background_image_file(self)
get_color(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples(self)
get_cubic_bezier_tuples_from_points(self, points)
# Information about line
get_end_anchors(self)
get_fill_color(self)
If there are multiple colors (for gradient)
this returns the first one
get_fill_colors(self)
get_fill_opacities(self)
get_fill_opacity(self)
If there are multiple opacities, this returns the
first
get_fill_rgbas(self)
get_gradient_start_and_end_points(self)
get_group_class(self)
get_last_point(self)
get_nth_curve_function(self, n)
get_nth_curve_points(self, n)
get_num_curves(self)
get_point_mobject(self, center=None)
The simplest mobject to be transformed to or from self.
Should by a point of the appropriate type
get_points(self)
get_points_defining_boundary(self)
get_sheen_direction(self)
get_sheen_factor(self)
get_start_anchors(self)

# Colors
insert_n_curves(self, n)
insert_n_curves_to_point_list(self, n, points)
interpolate_color(self, mobject1, mobject2, alpha)
is_closed(self)
make_jagged(self)
make_smooth(self)
match_background_image_file(self, vmobject)
match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)
point_from_proportion(self, alpha)
pointwise_become_partial(self, vmobject, a, b)
scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_opacity(self, opacity, family=True)
set_points(self, points)
# Points
set_points_as_corners(self, points)
set_points_smoothly(self, points)
set_shade_in_3d(self, value=True, z_index_as_group=False)
set_sheen(self, factor, direction=None, family=True)
set_sheen_direction(self, direction, family=True)
set_stroke(self, color=None, width=None, opacity=None, background=False, family=True)
set_style(self, fill_color=None, fill_opacity=None, stroke_color=None, stroke_width=None, stroke_opacity=None, background_stroke_color=None, background_stroke_width=None, background_stroke_opacity=None, sheen_factor=None, sheen_direction=None, background_image_file=None, family=True)
start_new_path(self, point)
update_rgbas_array(self, array_name, color=None, opacity=None)

add_n_more_submobjects(self, n)

add_updater(self, update_function, index=None, call_updater=True)
align_data(self, mobject)
# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2
apply_complex_function(self, function, **kwargs)
apply_function_to_position(self, function)
apply_function_to_submobject_positions(self, function)
apply_matrix(self, matrix, **kwargs)
apply_over_attr_arrays(self, func)
apply_points_function_about_point(self, func, about_point=None, about_edge=None)
apply_to_family(self, func)
arrange(self, direction=array([1., 0., 0.]), center=True, **kwargs)
arrange_in_grid(self, n_rows=None, n_cols=None, **kwargs)
arrange_submobjects(self, *args, **kwargs)
# Just here to keep from breaking old scenes.
become(self, mobject, copy_submobjects=True)
Edit points, colors and submobjects to be idential
to another mobject
become_partial(self, mobject, a, b)
Set points in such a way as to become only
part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.
center(self)
clear_updaters(self, recursive=True)
copy(self)
deepcopy(self)
digest_mobject_attrs(self)
Ensures all attributes which are mobjects are included
in the submobjects list.

Meant to generalize get_x, get_y, get_z
get_corner(self, direction)
get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

and mobject2.

nonempty_submobjects(self)
null_point_align(self, mobject)
If a mobject with points is being aligned to
one without, treat both as groups, and push
the one with points into its own submobjects
list.
pose_at_angle(self, **kwargs)
push_self_into_submobjects(self)

This can make transition animations nicer
repeat_submobject(self, submob)
replace(self, mobject, dim_to_match=0, stretch=False)
rescale_to_fit(self, length, dim, stretch=False, **kwargs)
reset_points(self)

resume_updating(self, recursive=True)
reverse_points(self)

rotate_about_origin(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]), axes=[])
rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))
save_image(self, name=None)
save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
set_color_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')
set_coord(self, value, dim, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_depth(self, depth, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_height(self, height, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_submobject_colors_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_submobject_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')
set_width(self, width, stretch=False, **kwargs)
set_x(self, x, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_y(self, y, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_z(self, z, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
shift(self, *vectors)
shift_onto_screen(self, **kwargs)
show(self, camera=None)
shuffle(self, recursive=False)

sort_submobjects(self, *args, **kwargs)
space_out_submobjects(self, factor=1.5, **kwargs)
split(self)

scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color

top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.

# Just here to keep from breaking old scenes.

Edit points, colors and submobjects to be idential
to another mobject
become_partial(self, mobject, a, b)
Set points in such a way as to become only
part of mobject.
Inputs 0 <= a < b <= 1 determine what portion
of mobject to become.

Meant to generalize get_x, get_y, get_z
get_corner(self, direction)
get_critical_point(self, direction)
Picture a box bounding the mobject.  Such a box has
9 'critical points': 4 corners, 4 edge center, the
center.  This returns one of them.

If a mobject with points is being aligned to
one without, treat both as groups, and push
the one with points into its own submobjects

rotate_in_place(self, angle, axis=array([0., 0., 1.]))
save_image(self, name=None)
save_state(self, use_deepcopy=False)
scale(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.
scale_about_point(self, scale_factor, point)
scale_in_place(self, scale_factor, **kwargs)
set_color_by_gradient(self, *colors)
set_colors_by_radial_gradient(self, center=None, radius=1, inner_color='#FFFFFF', outer_color='#000000')

set_width(self, width, stretch=False, **kwargs)

set_y(self, y, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))
set_z(self, z, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]))

Data descriptors inherited from manimlib.container.container.Container:
__dict__
dictionary for instance variables (if defined)
__weakref__
list of weak references to the object (if defined)

 
class Vector(Arrow)
    Vector(direction=array([1., 0., 0.]), **kwargs)
 
Meant for shared functionality between Arc and Line.
Functionality can be classified broadly into these groups:
 
    * Adding, Creating, Modifying tips
        - add_tip calls create_tip, before pushing the new tip
            into the TipableVMobject's list of submobjects
        - stylistic and positional configuration
 
    * Checking for tips
        - Boolean checks for whether the TipableVMobject has a tip
            and a starting tip
 
    * Getters
        - Straightforward accessors, returning information pertaining
            to the TipableVMobject instance's tip(s), its length etc
 
 
Method resolution order:
Vector
Arrow
Line
TipableVMobject
manimlib.mobject.types.vectorized_mobject.VMobject
manimlib.mobject.mobject.Mobject
manimlib.container.container.Container
builtins.object
Methods defined here:
__init__(self, direction=array([1., 0., 0.]), **kwargs)
Initialize self.  See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.
Data and other attributes defined here:
CONFIG = {'buff': 0}

# TODO, should this be the default for everything?

scale(self, factor, **kwargs)
Default behavior is to scale about the center of the mobject.
The argument about_edge can be a vector, indicating which side of
the mobject to scale about, e.g., mob.scale(about_edge = RIGHT)
scales about mob.get_right().
 
Otherwise, if about_point is given a value, scaling is done with
respect to that point.

Methods inherited from TipableVMobject:
add_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Adds a tip to the TipableVMobject instance, recognising
that the endpoints might need to be switched if it's
a 'starting tip' or not.
asign_tip_attr(self, tip, at_start)
create_tip(self, tip_length=None, at_start=False)
Stylises the tip, positions it spacially, and returns
the newly instantiated tip to the caller.

otherwise throws an exception.

generate_rgbas_array(self, color, opacity)
First arg can be either a color, or a tuple/list of colors.
Likewise, opacity can either be a float, or a tuple of floats.
If self.sheen_factor is not zero, and only
one color was passed in, a second slightly light color
will automatically be added for the gradient
get_anchors(self)
get_anchors_and_handles(self)
returns anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2,
where (anchors1[i], handles1[i], handles2[i], anchors2[i])
will be four points defining a cubic bezier curve
for any i in range(0, len(anchors1))

match_style(self, vmobject, family=True)
point_from_proportion(self, alpha)
pointwise_become_partial(self, vmobject, a, b)
scale_handle_to_anchor_distances(self, factor)
If the distance between a given handle point H and its associated
anchor point A is d, then it changes H to be a distances factor*d
away from A, but so that the line from A to H doesn't change.
This is mostly useful in the context of applying a (differentiable)
function, to preserve tangency properties.  One would pull all the
handles closer to their anchors, apply the function then push them out
again.
set_anchors_and_handles(self, anchors1, handles1, handles2, anchors2)
set_background_stroke(self, **kwargs)
set_color(self, color, family=True)
Condition is function which takes in one arguments, (x, y, z).
Here it just recurses to submobjects, but in subclasses this
should be further implemented based on the the inner workings
of color
set_fill(self, color=None, opacity=None, family=True)
set_points(self, points)

# Alignment
align_on_border(self, direction, buff=0.5)
Direction just needs to be a vector pointing towards side or
corner in the 2d plane.
align_points_with_larger(self, larger_mobject)
align_submobjects(self, mobject)
align_to(self, mobject_or_point, direction=array([0., 0., 0.]), alignment_vect=array([0., 1., 0.]))
Examples:
mob1.align_to(mob2, UP) moves mob1 vertically so that its
top edge lines ups with mob2's top edge.
 
mob1.align_to(mob2, alignment_vect = RIGHT) moves mob1
horizontally so that it's center is directly above/below
the center of mob2
